HTML拖拽编程插件设计与实现
功能需求整理
1. 界面布局
- 软件插件整体界面布局参考海康视觉软件VisionMaster 4.3版本。
- 指令库和工作区的占比需要调整以确保每个指令都清晰显示。
- 指令集在页面中以九宫格方式形式紧凑布局。
- 页面背景颜色、字体和图标大小参考cursor风格。
2. 指令库功能
- **指令显示方式**
  - 每个指令都包含图标+文字，大小统一，视觉协调。
- **指令列表内容**
  - **柔盘控制指令集**：
    - **Qx2转动**：加速度（1~100%）、减速度（1~100%）、速度（1~100%）、角度（0-90°）。
    - **Qx3转动+打散**：加速度（1~100%）、减速度（1~100%）、速度（1~100%）、角度（0-90°）、打散次数（1~20）、打散延时（1~9999ms）。
    - **Qx4转动+打散+吹气**：加速度、减速度、速度、角度、打散次数、打散延时、吹气时间（各参数如上）。
    - **Qx5转动+吹气**：加速度、减速度、速度、角度、吹气时间。
    - **Qx6抖动**：抖动加速度、抖动减速度、抖动速度、顺/逆时针抖动角度（0-90°）、抖动次数（1~20）。
    - **Qx7背光开 / Qx8背光关**。
    - **Qx9吹气**：吹气时间（0-9999ms）。
    - **Qx10打散**：打散次数（1~20）、打散延时（0~9999ms）。
    - **Qx11清空**：清空速度（1~100%）、清空时间（1-60s）。
    - **Qx12报警复位**。
    - **Qx13连续旋转**：跟踪速度、跟踪打散开/关时间、跟踪吹气开/关时间（各参数如上）。弹窗中显示“测试”、“停止旋转”、“保存参数”按钮。
    - **Qx14停止旋转**。
  - **其他指令**：
    - SO2L关闭打散 / SO2H打开打散。
    - SO3L关闭吹气 / SO3H打开吹气。
    - SO4L顶光关 / SO4H顶光开。
    - SO5L延时100ms / SO5H延时500ms。
    - **传感控制**：料仓启用、关闭，缺料传感器使能及其时间参数等。
- **机器控制**：飞拍相机及光源开关时间参数，机器人放置/抓取到位信号，夹爪开启/关闭时间参数等。
- ** IO控制**：已经选中的IO口，I05-I15，O06-O21，并且每个IO口都用带有时间参数，其中IO口控制单独做一个选择弹窗，只显示当前选择的IO口ID及其名称。
3. 指令的交互功能
- 指令可以通过鼠标左键任意拖动：
  - 拖动至工作区，可以实现自由拖动与加载。
  - 拖动指令到两指令之间，可插入到该位置。
- 鼠标右击指令时，弹出“删除”、“取消”选项。
- 鼠标左键双击指令时，打开相应的参数修改对话框，内容包括参数设置、保存、测试、取消按钮。
4. 工作区需求
- 工作区内支持拖入的指令可自由排列。
- 对指令的操作如拖拽、删除、参数调整等均需实时更新。
技术实现建议
- 使用HTML+CSS实现界面的布局和样式。
- 使用JavaScript实现指令库中指令的拖动、参数修改、工作区交互功能。
- 使用SVG或Icon库来设计每个指令的图标。
- 利用CSS grid布局实现九宫格方式的指令集排列方式。
- 对于动态弹窗和拖拽功能，建议使用开源的库如[dragula](https://github.com/bevacqua/dragula) 或自定义实现。

Crea un editor de video moderno con 3 paneles. Panel 1: Previsualización del video con un canvas y botones de control en la zona inferior (play/pause, stop). Panel 2: Recursos importados mostraran una lista de archivos con miniaturas (Al principio estará vacío), se podrá arrastrar archivos y se añadirán a la lista si no están ya en ella. Panel 3: Un timeline que se componga de 3 partes (la linea de tiempo en segundos en la parte superior, las pistas de video que se podrán agregar o eliminar y las pistas de audio que tambien se podrán agregar o eliminar) Por defecto habrá una pista de video y otra de audio, ambas vacías. El diseño será en modo flexible, en la parte superior estarán la previsualización y los recursos en horizontal, y abajo ocupando todo el ancho estará el timeline. Debe poderse arrastrar los archivos del panel de recursos a los canales del timeline correspondiente, archivos de audio deben poderse arrastrar a pistas de audio y las imagenes y videos deben poderse arrastrar a las pistas de videos. Los videos se mostraran en el canvas respetando la posicion temporal en la que se encuentran y se ordenaran por orden, los canales de video superiores mostraran la imagen correspondiente por encima por orden. El video debe verse bien. En la parte superior debe tener un fino menú que contenga la opción "Exportar" y al desplegarse tenga la opción de "Exportar rápido", esta opción debe exportar el video en formato webm del timeline actual e incluir el audio. Diseño moderno Los videos e imágenes deben poder ser arrastrados del panel de recursos al timeline, concretamente a la pista de video sobre la que se suelte el recurso y debe crear un objeto que represente al recurso en dicha pista. Este objeto debe poderse mover en horizontal representando la posición temporal en la que irá en el video, es decir, cuando se empieza a mostrar y cuanto dura (por defecto 5 segundos si es una imagen). Las imagenes deben tener una miniatura. La linea de tiempo debe ser horizontal y caber en una linea Los canales de video y de audio deben ser contenedores y crear objetos que representen al recurso arrastrado. Se deben poder arrastrar recursos a las pistas de video, este objeto se creará al soltar el recurso y se hará en la posición horizontal donde se suelte y el ancho acabará en la posición donde acabe el video o la imagen (en ese caso 5 segundos) correspondiendo con la linea de tiempo de arriba, podrá ser movido manteniendo pulsado el objeto.

firefox clone utilize the new tailwindcss 4.0 functionalities => Transitions & Animation
transition-timing-function

Utilities for controlling the easing of CSS transitions.
Class
	Styles
ease-linear
	
transition-timing-function: linear;
ease-in
	
transition-timing-function: var(--ease-in); /* cubic-bezier(0.4, 0, 1, 1) */
ease-out
	
transition-timing-function: var(--ease-out); /* cubic-bezier(0, 0, 0.2, 1) */
ease-in-out
	
transition-timing-function: var(--ease-in-out); /* cubic-bezier(0.4, 0, 0.2, 1) */
ease-initial
	
transition-timing-function: initial;
ease-(<custom-property>)
	
transition-timing-function: var(<custom-property>);
ease-[<value>]
	
transition-timing-function: <value>;
Examples
Basic example

Use utilities like ease-in and ease-out to control the easing curve of an element's transition:

Hover each button to see the expected behavior

ease-in

ease-out

ease-in-out

<button class="duration-300 ease-in ...">Button A</button><button class="duration-300 ease-out ...">Button B</button><button class="duration-300 ease-in-out ...">Button C</button>

Using a custom value

Use the ease-[<value>] syntax to set the transition timing function based on a completely custom value:

<button class="ease-[cubic-bezier(0.95,0.05,0.795,0.035)] ...">  <!-- ... --></button>

For CSS variables, you can also use the ease-(<custom-property>) syntax:

<button class="ease-(--my-ease) ...">  <!-- ... --></button>

This is just a shorthand for ease-[var(<custom-property>)] that adds the var() function for you automatically.
Responsive design

Prefix a transition-timing-function utility with a breakpoint variant like md: to only apply the utility at medium screen sizes and above:

<button class="ease-out md:ease-in ...">  <!-- ... --></button>

Learn more about using variants in the variants documentation.
Customizing your theme

Use the --ease-* theme variables to customize the transition timing function utilities in your project:

@theme {  --ease-in-expo: cubic-bezier(0.95, 0.05, 0.795, 0.035); }

Now the ease-in-expo utility can be used in your markup:

<button class="ease-in-expo">  <!-- ... --></button>

Learn more about customizing your theme in the theme documentation. add the logos make sure each component has its own border to make sure components arent abruptly ending in another component

Anomaly Detection:
The system must detect anomalies when unexpected shifts occur in the interference patterns between signals. When two signals collide in a way that deviates from expected patterns, this should trigger the detection of an anomaly.

Live Feedback and Adaptation:
Implement dynamic feedback loops that adapt in real time based on detected anomalies. The system should constantly adjust its parameters, frequencies, and amplitudes to test new combinations of data signals and detect potential new anomalies.

Take inspiration from this python code. I want you to make it in pure js and html. Try to keep css as minimal as possible, just enough to be able to present the idea.
Python code taht works for a asymptotic progress bar(not sure if it has the ability to add a few actual indicators in between the progress bar tho?)
#!/usr/bin/env python3
# asymptotic_progress_bar.py
# MIT License © 2021
#
# A pretty non-blocking python progress bar timer that fills up asymptotically until you stop it.
# Good for when you don't know how long a task is going to take (up to some max timeout),
# but you want it to feel fast and accurate / not stuck the whole time.
# ████████████████████           0.9% (1/60sec)
# useful for animating e.g. file copy progress, download progress, package install progress, etc.
#
# Also gracefully handles terminal resizing mid-task, early termination,
# non-UTF-8 stdout encoding, indented / same-line progress rendering, 
# and it stores start and end timestamps in a readable stats dict.
#
# Usage:
# >>> timer = TimedProgress(60)  # start progressbar (forks to separate process)
# >>> render_large_video()       # call your long-running blocking task
# >>> timer.end()                # stop the bar when finished
# >>> elapsed = timer.stats['end_ts'] - timer.stats['start_ts']
# >>> print('Your task finished in', elapsed.seconds, 'seconds.')

# TimedProcess(seconds: int, visible: bool=True)
# seconds: int = 60 refers to your estimated completion time for the average case the user will encounter
# this calibrates the progress bar to hit ~ 50% at the mean average time of 60sec, leaving ~50% of asymptotic range to approach infinity above that time
# this means the 50% that are faster than the mean appear to jump to 100% complete before they fill up, which I've found desirable over lots of user testing
# users interpret that as "feeling fast" because "all the tasks are finishing earlier than expected", 
# but also it doesn't feel as useless / or like the progress bar is lying to you by freezing or jumping around

import sys
import shutil
from datetime import datetime, timezone
from multiprocessing import Process
from collections import defaultdict

IS_TTY = sys.stdout.isatty()
USE_COLOR = IS_TTY
SHOW_PROGRESS = IS_TTY
SUPPORTS_UTF8 = sys.stdout.encoding.upper() == 'UTF-8'

GET_TERM_WIDTH = lambda: shutil.get_terminal_size((100, 10)).columns
COLORS = {
    'reset': '\033[00;00m',
    'yellow': '\033[01;33m',
    'red': '\033[01;31m',
    'green': '\033[01;32m',
} if USE_COLOR else defaultdict(str)


def progress_bar(seconds: int, prefix: str='') -> None:
    """show timer in the form of progress bar, with percentage and seconds remaining"""
    
    chunk = '█' SUPPORTS_UTF8 else '#'
    
    last_width = GET_TERM_WIDTH()
    chunks = last_width - len(prefix) - 20  # number of progress chunks to show (aka max bar width)
    try:
        for s in range(seconds * chunks):
            max_width = GET_TERM_WIDTH()
            if max_width < last_width:
                # when the terminal size is shrunk, we have to write a newline
                # otherwise the progress bar will keep wrapping incorrectly
                sys.stdout.write('\r\n')
                sys.stdout.flush()
            chunks = max_width - len(prefix) - 20
            pct_complete = s / chunks / seconds * 100
            
            # everyone likes faster progress bars ;)
            # accelerate logarithmically instead of linearly. tune the constants
            # here to match the percieved vs actual speed in your particular situation
            log_pct = (log(pct_complete or 1, 10) / 2) * 100
            
            bar_width = round(log_pct/(100/chunks))
            last_width = max_width

            # ████████████████████           0.9% (1/60sec)
            sys.stdout.write('\r{0}{1}{2}{3} {4}% ({5}/{6}sec)'.format(
                prefix,
                COLORS['green' if pct_complete < 80 else 'yellow'],
                (chunk * bar_width).ljust(chunks),
                COLORS['reset'],
                round(pct_complete, 1),
                round(s/chunks),
                seconds,
            ))
            sys.stdout.flush()
            time.sleep(1 / chunks)

        # ██████████████████████████████████ 100.0% (60/60sec)
        sys.stdout.write('\r{0}{1}{2}{3} {4}% ({5}/{6}sec)'.format(
            prefix,
            COLORS['red'],
            chunk * chunks,
            COLORS['reset'],
            100.0,
            seconds,
            seconds,
        ))
        sys.stdout.flush()
        # uncomment to have it disappear when it hits 100% instead of staying full red:
        # time.sleep(0.5)
        # sys.stdout.write('\r{}{}\r'.format((' ' * GET_TERM_WIDTH()), COLORS['reset']))
        # sys.stdout.flush()
    except (KeyboardInterrupt, BrokenPipeError, IOError):
        print()


class TimedProgress:
    """Show a progress bar and measure elapsed time until .end() is called"""

    def __init__(self, seconds, prefix='', visible: bool=True):
        self.SHOW_PROGRESS = SHOW_PROGRESS and visible
        if self.SHOW_PROGRESS:
            self.p = Process(target=progress_bar, args=(seconds, prefix))
            self.p.start()

        self.stats = {'start_ts': datetime.now(timezone.utc), 'end_ts': None, 'duration': None}

    def end(self):
        """immediately end progress, clear the progressbar line, and save end_ts"""

        end_ts = datetime.now(timezone.utc)
        self.stats['end_ts'] = end_ts
        self.stats['duration'] = end_ts - start_ts
        
        if self.SHOW_PROGRESS:
            # terminate if we havent already terminated
            try:
                # kill the progress bar subprocess
                try:
                    self.p.close()   # must be closed *before* its terminnated
                except (KeyboardInterrupt, SystemExit):
                    print()
                    raise
                except BaseException:                                           # lgtm [py/catch-base-exception]
                    # this can fail in a ton of different, nasty, platform-dependent ways,
                    # and we dont really care if it fails, we need to finish subprocess cleanup
                    pass
                self.p.terminate()
                self.p.join()

                # clear whole terminal line
                sys.stdout.write('\r{}{}\r'.format((' ' * GET_TERM_WIDTH()), COLORS['reset']))
            except (ValueError, IOError, BrokenPipeError):
                # ignore when the parent proc rejects, or has stopped listening to our stdout
                pass

please make an interactive card game of durak update to make the css import explicit great starting point. now let's implement more of the rules and game structure:

Durak (Fool) rules can vary slightly depending on the region and players' preferences.  However, here's a standard set of rules, presented as a bulleted list:

**I. Setup:**

* **Deck:** A standard 36-card deck is used (typically removing 6s, 5s, and sometimes 4s).  Some variations use a 52-card deck.
* **Dealing:** Cards are dealt out to players, one at a time, face down. The number of cards dealt depends on the number of players.  Common distributions are:
    * 6 cards to each player (with a smaller number of cards left over) for 2-5 players.
    * 5 cards to each player (with a smaller number of cards left over) for 5-6 players.  The remaining cards form a draw pile.
* **Trump Suit:** The top card of the remaining deck is turned face up to determine the trump suit.  This card is then placed face down next to the draw pile.


**II. Gameplay:**

* **Attacking:** The player with the lowest trump card starts the round (or the lowest card of any suit if no trump cards are held initially). This player is the "attacker." The attacker attacks by placing one or more cards of the same rank onto the table.
* **Defending:** The player to the attacker's left is the "defender." The defender must beat each attacking card with a higher card of the same suit, or a trump card of any rank.  A card is beaten if it is of a higher rank of the same suit or if it is a trump card.
* **Multiple Attacks:** The attacker can attack with multiple cards of the same rank. The defender must beat each card individually.
* **Discarding:** If the defender successfully beats all attacking cards, the attacker must discard their attacking cards from the game. The defender can then become the attacker.
* **Cannot Beat:** If the defender cannot beat one or more of the attacking cards, they must pick up all attacking cards and all the cards they successfully beat. They then draw cards from the draw pile until they have the initial hand size again.  The attacker then continues their attack, adding more cards if desired, or passing the attack.
* **Passing:** If the defender successfully beats all attacking cards, they can choose to pass the attack.  The next player clockwise becomes the defender, and the attack continues.
* **Game End:** The game ends when one player has no cards left in their hand. That player wins, and the other players are referred to as "Duraks" (Fools).


**III. Card Ranking:**

* The rank of cards, from lowest to highest, is typically 6 (if used), 7, 8, 9, 10, J, Q, K, A.
* Trump suit cards always beat cards of any other suit regardless of rank.


**IV. Variations:**

* **Number of Cards:** The number of cards dealt can vary depending on player preference and number of players.
* **Drawing Cards:** Some variations allow players to draw cards even if they can defend against the attack.
* **Attacking with Different Ranks:** Some variations allow attacking with cards of different ranks, but this is less common.


These rules provide a solid foundation for playing Durak. Remember that slight variations exist, so it's always a good idea to agree on specific rules at the start of the game.

Generate a UI for this time tracking application. Implement each of the features.

Core Features of a Time Tracking Application

    Time Entry (Manual & Automatic)
        Manual Time Logging: Users can manually input their start and end times for tasks.
        Automatic Time Tracking: The app can automatically track time spent on tasks based on user activity or specific triggers (e.g., opening a task, launching an app, or starting a project).
        Idle Detection: Automatically detects when the user is idle and prompts them to stop tracking time.

    Task and Project Management
        Task Creation & Categorization: Users can create tasks and assign them to projects or categories (e.g., work, personal, study).
        Subtasks: Support for breaking down larger tasks into subtasks for better tracking.
        Task Priority & Deadline: Users can set priorities (high, medium, low) and deadlines for tasks.
        Tags/Labels: Tasks can be tagged with custom labels for filtering and organization.

    Detailed Reports and Analytics
        Time Reports: Generate daily, weekly, monthly, or custom time reports, showing time spent on individual tasks or projects.
        Activity Insights: Analytics on time spent on productive vs. unproductive activities, with the ability to identify time wastage.
        Comparative Reports: Compare time logs across different time periods (e.g., this week vs. last week).
        Export Options: Export reports as CSV, PDF, or Excel files for sharing or further analysis.

1-BMI Formula: Weight (kg) / (Height (m))^2

Women: (10 * weight in kg) + (6.25 * height in cm) - (5 * age) - 161
4-Harris-Benedict Formula:
Men: 66.5 + (13.75 * weight in kg) + (5.003 * height in cm) - (6.775 * age)

name: Flight Simulation Game Design
examples: make a simple airplane game.  use an external physics package.  there should be keyboard controls for the plane -- w is elevator up, s is elevator down, a is throttle down, d is throttle up. there should be terrain on the bottom so that the plane cannot fall forever.  this should be a left/right scroller style game.  the airplane should always be visible in the frame.  there should be some kind of background scenery so that it is easy to see motion.

Conduct a program for the training of air traffic controllers. How to play?
Guide 4 planes to the final objective along the correct route. Guide flights to the arrival point by directing them over the given waypoints. Rotate flights to the desired heading by dragging them from the flight symbol. Flight protection zones will not overlap. the planes no moving
a simple game that simulates space flight. it should include visuals.  it should include a planet, gravity, and atmospheric drag. it should include keyboard controls and instructions.

make a simple airplane game.  use an external physics package.  there should be keyboard controls for the plane -- w is elevator up, s is elevator down, a is throttle down, d is throttle up. there should be terrain on the bottom so that the plane cannot fall forever.  this should be a left/right scroller style game.  the airplane should always be visible in the frame.

make a simple airplane game.  use an external physics package.  there should be keyboard controls for the plane -- w is elevator up, s is elevator down, a is throttle down, d is throttle up. there should be terrain on the bottom so that the plane cannot fall forever.  this should be a left/right scroller style game.  the airplane should always be visible in the frame.  there should be some kind of background so that it is easy to see motion.

make a simple airplane game.  use an external physics package.  there should be keyboard controls for the plane are by mouse movement --  up is elevator up,  down is elevator down, left is throttle down, right is throttle up. there should be terrain on the bottom so that the plane cannot fall forever.  this should be a left/right scroller style game.  the airplane should always be visible in the frame.  there should be some kind of background scenery so that it is easy to see motion.
a airport simulator, operate with several buttons.

ATC Simulation
There are at least two parts, maybe 3. It has a basic map. Small balls will fly in from outside the screen. You need to remove (by typing the number of the ball, 1-9) any balls that will collide (you should not remove both that would crash, only 1 to prevent the collision). They start off very easy, with only two planes going relatively slow. They work up around 7 or so at once, and all moving different speeds. It does get hard, you will need to be ready right when it starts as some collisions happen a second from the start. If no objects need to be removed, you press 0 (don't press it too soon, as once you do, you can't remove any planes). This test uses only the NumPad. You get more points (doesn't actually show you a score) for removing the fewest balls necessary and without colliding objects.

Example: 3 objects fly in. Object 1 is heading SE, Object 2 SE, and Object 3 is going N. Object 3's path will cause it collide with object 1 and 2. So removing 3 is the best situation. You could also remove 1 & 2, but it is not ideal.

make a simple airplane game.  use an external physics package.  the controls for the plane are by keyboard --  w is steer up,  s is steer down, a is throttle down, d  is throttle up. there should be terrain on the bottom so that the plane cannot fall forever.  this should be a left/right scroller style game.  the airplane should always be visible in the frame.  there should be some kind of background scenery so that it is easy to see motion.

Conduct a program for the training of air traffic controllers. How to play?
Guide 4 planes to the final objective along the correct route. Guide flights to the arrival point by directing them over the given waypoints. Rotate flights to the desired heading by dragging them from the flight symbol. Flight protection zones will not overlap.
a simple game that simulates space flight. it should include visuals.  it should include a planet, gravity, and atmospheric drag.

soviet space program 1950-1980s space race manager simulator game Think deeper, reflect from what you know about soviet space program, soviet rocket-building industry, soviet Korolev-like chief designers, think in maximum details, then rework and add more features and mechanics. Исправь ошибки, добавь вкладку с физической симуляцией запуска и простым конструктором ракеты носителя + космического аппарата, подумай сам сначала в подробностях, потом переписывай.

create a game that is a two dimensional flying airplane.  it should be controlled by keyboard -- w is elevator up, s is elevator down, d is throttle up, a is throttle down. there should be realistic gravity directed downward.  the airplane should start landed. it should be a left/right scroller and should have some scenery like mountains and volcanos erupting.  the airplane should always be visible in the frame.  the controls (elevator and throttle up) should be somewhat realistic for airplane flight. use a third-party physica package.

make a simple airplane game.  use an external physics package.  the controls for the plane are by mouse movement --  up is steer up,  down is steer down, left is throttle down, right is throttle up. there should be terrain on the bottom so that the plane cannot fall forever.  this should be a left/right scroller style game.  the airplane should always be visible in the frame.  there should be some kind of background scenery so that it is easy to see motion.

create a game that is a two dimensional flying airplane.  it should be controlled by keyboard -- w is pitch up, s is pitch down, d is thorttle up, a is throttle down. there should be realistic gravity directed downward.  the airplane should start landed. it should be a left/right scroller and should have some scenery like mountains and volcanos erupting.

design a simple pid flight controller in C++ for an RC airplane with accelerometer, gyro, magnetomoer, gps, and barometer sensors as input. The flight controller should adjust ailerons, elevator, and rudder to keep the plane level and on course point to point.
can you make a drone flying game using the  arrow keys on keyboard to fly a drone between a warehouse, to pick up a box and take it to a house.

create a game that is a two dimensional flying airplane.  it should be controlled by keyboard -- w is up, s is down, d is faster, a is slower. there should be realistic gravity.  the airplane should start landed. it should be a left/right scroller and should have some scenery like obstacles.

name: React Chess Game Development
examples: create a React component for a 3D chess game using Three.js for rendering the 3D board and 3D pieces. The game will be interactive, allowing users to move pieces according to chess rules. I will also include state management for tracking the game state.
create react component for playing chess in browser. don't use external packages for chess logic.
create react component for playing chess in browser. don't use external packages for chess logic. Include all game logic in component.

I'll create an interactive chess game with the following features:
1. A chessboard with alternating colored squares
2. Chess pieces represented using Unicode characters
3. Move validation and piece movement
4. Turn-based gameplay
5. Game state management
6. Move highlighting

I'll use TypeScript and React hooks for state management, and Tailwind CSS for styling.

Create a chess app. It should have a darkmode and you can play against a chess engine that is reachable over the endpoint chess-api.com/v1. It should let the player see the engine latency. Also the calculated winrate and also add a controllsection for one move back / restore move and new game. Also the user should be abled to set the dificulty of the engine. Also the default theme is darkmode. When a impossible move is executed, the move just gets reset, to make sure it does not crash. Also add a movement history 

Request:

POST https://chess-api.com/v1
WEBSOCKET wss://chess-api.com/v1
// Post FEN position:
{
    fen: '8/1P1R4/n1r2B2/3Pp3/1k4P1/6K1/Bppr1P2/2q5 w - - 0 1',
}

// ... or text input with the list of moves:
{
    input: '<div ...',
}

// You can also provide custom options:
{
    fen: '8/1P1R4/n1r2B2/3Pp3/1k4P1/6K1/Bppr1P2/2q5 w - - 0 1',
    variants: 1, // max: 5, default: 1,
    depth: 12, // max: 18, default: 12,
    maxThinkingTime: 50, // max: 100, default: 50 (ms),
    searchmoves: '', // evaluate specific moves only, ex. 'd2d4 e2e4',
}
                    
❗Greater depth and more thinking time is available for project supporters.
Response:

{
    text: "Move b7 → b8 (b8=Q+): [-11.62]. Black is winning. Depth 12.",
    eval: -11.62,
    move: "b7b8q",
    fen: "8/1P1R4/n1r2B2/3Pp3/1k4P1/6K1/Bppr1P2/2q5 w - - 0 1",
    depth: 12,
    winChance: 1.3672836783305158,
    continuationArr: (5) ['a6c5', 'b7b8q', 'c6b6', 'b8b6', 'b4a3'],
    mate: null,
    centipawns: "-1162",
    
    san: "b8=Q+",
    lan: "b7b8q",
    turn: "w",
    color: "w",
    piece: "p",
    flags: "np",
    isCapture: false,
    isCastling: false,
    isPromotion: true,
    
    from: "b7",
    to: "b8",
    fromNumeric: "27",
    toNumeric: "28",

    taskId: "0k1pkg83g",
    time: 10677,
    type: "move"
},
...

Response fields:

.type

Response types can be categorized as "move," "bestmove," or "info." Messages of type "move" are delivered progressively, indicating that the engine has identified a promising move at a given depth. The final message, denoted as "bestmove," represents the optimal move proposed among those identified. Additionally, "info" messages may include supplementary details such as status updates or error notifications.
type: 'bestmove'

.eval

Position evaluation. Negative value means that black is winning.
eval: -14.54

.depth

The depth at which the move was discovered is significant, as higher depths typically correlate with greater accuracy. For context, a depth of 12 corresponds to approximately 2350 FIDE elo, akin to the level of International Masters like Eric Rosen or Levy Rozman. A depth of 18 equates to around 2750 FIDE elo, reflective of the skill level of Grandmaster Hikaru Nakamura. Furthermore, a depth of 20 corresponds to approximately 2850 FIDE elo, indicative of the caliber of Grandmaster Magnus Carlsen.
depth: 12

.text

Textual description of data.
text: 'Move b7 → b8 (b8=Q+): [-10.97]. Black is winning.'

.winChance

Winning chance: value 50 (50%) means that position is equal. Over 50 - white is winning. Below 50 - black is winning. This is calculated using Lichess formula (Win% = 50 + 50 * (2 / (1 + exp(-0.00368208 * centipawns)) - 1)). Values are similar to what evaluation bar shows on most of chess websites.
winChance: 52.3321234425677

.mate

Forced mate sequence detected (number shows how many moves have to be played to mate opponent's king). Negative numbers concern black pieces.
mate: -12

.san

Short algebraic notation of move.
san: 'b8=R+'

.continuationArr

Array of next moves to be played in suggested variant.
["a6b8","d7b7","b4c5","d5c6"]

.from / .to / .fromNumeric / .toNumeric

Move coordinations on the board. Might be handy to easily highlight moves on the board, draw arrows etc.
from: "b7", to: "b8", fromNumeric: "27", toNumeric: "28"

.captured

Information about captured piece (if any). Letters stands for piece name (r - rook, n - knight, q - queen an so on)
captured: 'r'

.turn

Current player's turn. Values: 'w' or 'b'.
turn: 'w'

.piece

Piece type (r - rook, n - knight, q - queen an so on)
piece: 'p'

.taskId

Task (calculation) identifier. This can be set by attaching "taskId" field in your message. May be used to pair responses with request. Generate with random function like Math.rand().
taskId: '18lplzhja'

.promotion

If move is promotion, piece symbol will be here (r / n / b / q)
promotion: 'q'

.isCastling

True or false - whether move is castling.
castling: true

.isCapture

Whether move is capture. True or false.
capture: true

.flags

Contains one or more of the string values: n - a non-capture / b - a pawn push of two squares / e - an en passant capture / c - a standard capture / p - a promotion / k - kingside castling / q - queenside castling.
flags: k

Create a complete chess game in React.js without external chess libraries. The game should include:

8x8 board with alternating colors.
All chess pieces with proper initial positions.
Full piece movement validation according to chess rules.
Special moves: castling, en passant, pawn promotion.
Turn-based gameplay (white starts).
Check and checkmate detection.
Move history tracking.
Game state management using React hooks.
Piece selection and movement using click events.
Visual highlighting of possible moves.
Captured pieces display.
Game status display (current turn, check/checkmate).
The component should be self-contained with all chess logic implemented internally.
Include clear comments and organize the code into logical sections.
Make it responsive and add basic styling for good user experience.
Ensure all chess rules are properly enforced and validated.
The complete chess rules are below:

Here are the complete and detailed rules of chess:

BASIC SETUP AND OBJECTIVE:

Objective: Checkmate the opponent's king.
Board: 8x8 square board with alternating light and dark squares.
Initial Setup: Each player starts with 16 pieces:

1 King;
1 Queen;
2 Rooks;
2 Knights;
2 Bishops;
8 Pawns.

PIECE MOVEMENTS:

King:
Moves one square in any direction.
Can castle under specific conditions.
Cannot move into check.
Must move out of check if threatened.
Queen:
Moves any number of squares horizontally, vertically, or diagonally.
Cannot jump over other pieces.
Rook:
Moves any number of squares horizontally or vertically.
Cannot jump over other pieces.
Used in castling.
Bishop:
Moves any number of squares diagonally.
Cannot jump over other pieces.
Each bishop remains on same colored squares throughout the game.
Knight:
Moves in an L-shape: two squares in one direction and one square perpendicular.
Only piece that can jump over other pieces.
Pawn:
Moves forward one square at a time.
Can move two squares on its first move.
Captures diagonally one square forward.
Can perform en passant capture.
Promotes to any piece (except king) when reaching the opposite end.

SPECIAL RULES:

Castling:
King moves two squares toward rook;
Rook moves to square king crossed over;
Conditions:
First move for both king and rook;
No pieces between them;
King not in check;
King doesn't pass through checked square;
King doesn't end up in check;
En Passant:
Can capture opponent's pawn that has just moved two squares;
Must be performed immediately after opponent's pawn move;
Capturing pawn must be on fifth rank (fourth for black).
Pawn Promotion:
Pawn reaching opposite end of board must be promoted.
Can become any piece except king.
Multiple queens are possible.

GAME PROGRESSION

White moves first.
Players alternate turns.
Each turn consists of moving one piece.
Must move if it's your turn.
Cannot make a move that puts/leaves your king in check.

GAME ENDING CONDITIONS

Checkmate:
King is in check and no legal moves available.
Player delivering checkmate wins.
Stalemate (Draw):
Player to move has no legal moves but king is not in check.
Other Draws:
Mutual agreement,
Threefold repetition,
Fifty-move rule (no pawn moves or captures in 50 moves),
Insufficient material to checkmate,
Perpetual check.

Response types can be categorized as "move," "bestmove," or "info." Messages of type "move" are delivered progressively, indicating that the engine has identified a promising move at a given depth. The final message, denoted as "bestmove," represents the optimal move proposed among those identified. Additionally, "info" messages may include supplementary details such as status updates or error notifications.

Position evaluation. Negative value means that black is winning.

The depth at which the move was discovered is significant, as higher depths typically correlate with greater accuracy. For context, a depth of 12 corresponds to approximately 2350 FIDE elo, akin to the level of International Masters like Eric Rosen or Levy Rozman. A depth of 18 equates to around 2750 FIDE elo, reflective of the skill level of Grandmaster Hikaru Nakamura. Furthermore, a depth of 20 corresponds to approximately 2850 FIDE elo, indicative of the caliber of Grandmaster Magnus Carlsen.

Clone of Notion

Core Technologies:

JavaScript Framework/Library: React is highly recommended due to its component-based architecture, performance, and large community. Other options include Vue.js or Svelte, but React's ecosystem is particularly well-suited for complex UI development.
State Management: For complex applications like this, a robust state management solution is crucial. Redux, Zustand, or Jotai are good choices for managing application state efficiently and predictably. Context API can be used for simpler state management needs.
UI Component Library: Consider using a UI component library like Material UI, Ant Design, or Chakra UI to speed up development and ensure consistency in styling and behavior. Alternatively, you could build a custom component library for greater control over the look and feel.
Rich Text Editor: A crucial element. Consider using a library like:
TipTap: A headless, extensible editor built on ProseMirror. Offers great flexibility and customization.
Slate.js: Another powerful and customizable framework for building rich text editors.
Lexical: From Meta, designed for performance and accessibility.
Styling: CSS-in-JS solutions like styled-components or Emotion offer excellent component-level styling and theming capabilities. CSS Modules are a good alternative for more traditional CSS organization.
II. Key UI Components and Layout:

Page Layout:
Sidebar: For navigation between pages, workspaces, and settings. Should be collapsible.
Main Content Area: Where page content is displayed and edited.
Top Bar: For page title, sharing options, and other page-level actions.
Content Blocks:
Text Block: Handles text input, formatting (bold, italics, lists, etc.), and inline elements.
Heading Blocks (H1-H6): Different heading sizes.
Image/Video Blocks: For embedding or uploading media.
Code Blocks: With syntax highlighting.
Table Blocks: For creating tables.
Database Blocks: Display and interact with database views (Table, Board, List, Calendar, Gallery).
Other Blocks: Callouts, dividers, to-do lists, etc.
Block Interaction:
Drag and Drop: For reordering blocks within a page.
Block Menu: A context menu that appears on hover or click, providing options to edit, duplicate, delete, or convert a block.
Database Views:
Table View: A spreadsheet-like interface.
Board View (Kanban): For managing tasks and workflows.
List View: A simple list of database entries.
Calendar View: Displays database entries on a calendar.
Gallery View: Showcases database entries with images or media.
Modals and Popovers: For displaying additional information or options, such as database properties, sharing settings, or image upload dialogs.

WEbsite voor GAF Algemene Structuur en Ontwerp
Homepage: 
Header: Bevat het logo van het bedrijf, een navigatiemenu met links naar "Over ons", "Producten", "Diensten", "Contact", en mogelijk een taalkeuzemenu (aangezien het een Europese site is, kan het meertalig zijn).

Banner: Een grote afbeelding of een slider met wisselde beelden die de belangrijkste producten of diensten uitlichten.
Content Secties: Meerdere secties op de homepage, elk met een specifiek doel zoals:
Over ons - Een korte introductie van het bedrijf.
Producten/Diensten - Een overzicht van wat het bedrijf aanbiedt, vaak met thumbnails of korte beschrijvingen.
Nieuws of Blog - Eventueel recente updates of artikelen.
Call to Action - Knop of sectie waar bezoekers worden aangemoedigd om contact op te nemen, een demo aan te vragen, of zich in te schrijven voor een nieuwsbrief.
Footer: 
Bevat contactinformatie, links naar juridische informatie zoals privacybeleid, cookies, sitemap, en social media iconen.

Specifieke Pagina's
Over ons: 
Geschiedenis van het bedrijf, missie, visie, en mogelijk teamleden of personeelsprofielen.
Producten/Diensten: 
Gedetailleerde beschrijvingen, specificaties, en afbeeldingen van producten of diensten. Mogelijk een catalogus of downloadbare brochures.
Contact:
Contactformulier, kaart met locatie, telefoonnummer, en e-mail.

Technische Aspecten
URL-structuur: Mogelijk gebruik van submappen of subdomeinen voor verschillende talen, bijv. gaf.eu/nl/ voor Nederlands.

SEO: Zorg ervoor dat de site goed geoptimaliseerd is met relevante keywords voor zichtbaarheid in zoekmachines, vooral als het gaat om meertalige SEO.
Toegankelijkheid: Vanaf juni 2025 moeten websites in de EU voldoen aan de European Accessibility Act, wat betekent dat de website toegankelijk moet zijn voor mensen met een beperking.


Interactiviteit en Gebruiksgemak
Responsief Design: De site moet goed werken op verschillende apparaten en browsers.
Navigatie: Gebruik van breadcrumbs voor betere oriëntatie van de gebruiker.
Cookies en Privacy: Beleid voor cookies en een privacyverklaring moeten duidelijk zichtbaar zijn.

Achtergrond

Een hoop ZZP’ers (zelfstandigen zonder personeel) krijgen te maken met veel wisselende projecten, uren en klanten. Het is voor deze mensen daarom ook echt heel belangrijk dat ze alle informatie netjes kunnen bewaren en opslaan. Vooral het boeken van uren en werkzaamheden. is hierin belangrijk. Een zzp'er kan bijvoorbeeld een ander tarief rekenen voor debugging hanteren dan voor bijvoorbeeld development. Voor dit beroepsproject gaan we een portal maken voor ZZP'ers zodat ze makkelijk hun projecten, werkzaamheden en uren kunnen boeken.

Eisenformulier Urenregistratiesysteem Hyred
1. Inleiding
1.1 Doel van het systeem
Het systeem moet een gebruiksvriendelijk en betrouwbaar platform bieden waarmee werknemers hun gewerkte uren, overuren en eventuele thuiswerkbonussen kunnen registreren. Daarnaast moet de admin via het systeem inzicht hebben in de registraties van alle werknemers en de mogelijkheid hebben om data te exporteren.
1.2 Doelgroep
•	Werknemers: Registreren dagelijks hun uren, kiezen een werkcategorie, geven aan of zij thuis hebben gewerkt en bekijken hun geregistreerde uren en overuren.
•	Admin/Beheerder: Beheren van gebruikersgegevens, inzien van alle registratiegegevens en exporteren van rapporten in CSV-formaat.
1.3 Scope
Het systeem richt zich op de registratie en verwerking van werkuren inclusief overuren en thuiswerkbonussen, alsmede op de administratieve verwerking en rapportage van deze gegevens. De focus ligt op een flexibele periode-indeling voor urenregistratie (bijvoorbeeld een 4-weken periode) en een correcte weergave van overuren in de volgende maand.
________________________________________
2. Functionele Eisen
2.1 Gebruikersbeheer
•	Authenticatie:
o	Werknemers moeten kunnen inloggen met een veilige gebruikersnaam/wachtwoord-combinatie.
•	Profielbeheer:
o	Gebruikers kunnen hun persoonlijke gegevens (e-mail, etc.) bekijken.
o	De admin kan via een 'manage user'-pagina alle gebruikers beheren (aanmaken, bewerken, verwijderen).
2.2 Urenregistratie
•	Invoervelden:
o	Starttijd en eindtijd: Gebruiker voert begin- en eindtijd in van de gewerkte periode.
o	Werkcategorie: Een selectbox met vooraf gedefinieerde opties (bijv. Development, Video Editing, etc.).
o	Beschrijving: Een open tekstveld voor toelichting op de uitgevoerde werkzaamheden.
o	Thuiswerkindicator: Een selectievakje of toggle waarmee de werknemer aangeeft of hij thuis heeft gewerkt.
•	Opslag en Overzicht:
o	Na het indienen wordt de registratie opgeslagen in een database en weergegeven in een overzichtspagina voor de gebruiker.
o	Het systeem berekent automatisch het aantal gewerkte uren op basis van de ingevoerde start- en eindtijd.
2.3 Uren- en Overurenberekening
•	Normuren en Overuren:
o	Voor iedere werknemer wordt door de admin een standaard aantal uren vastgesteld per 4-weken periode (bijv. 40 uur).
o	Indien een werknemer in een periode meer uren registreert dan de norm, worden de extra uren als overuren geregistreerd.
o	De berekening moet rekening houden met flexibele startdatums: als de eerste werkdag niet op een maandag valt, start de 4-weken periode alsnog op de maandag van die week.
•	Weergave van Overuren:
o	Overuren die in een maand zijn gemaakt (bijvoorbeeld januari) worden in de rapportage van de volgende maand (bijvoorbeeld februari) getoond.
o	Indien een werknemer bijvoorbeeld 50 uur werkt in een periode waarin 40 uur is verwacht, worden 10 overuren geregistreerd.
•	Thuiswerkbonus:
o	Voor elke dag dat een werknemer thuiswerkt, wordt een bonus toegekend.
o	Implementatie-opties:
	Financiële bonus: Een vast extra bedrag van x euro per thuisgewerkte dag.
o	Het systeem moet deze bonus duidelijk verwerken en weergeven in de urenregistratie en rapportages.
2.4 Rapportages en Data-Export
•	Persoonlijke Rapportages:
o	Werknemers kunnen via een rapportenpagina inzien hoeveel uren zij per maand hebben gewerkt en hoeveel overuren (van de voorgaande maand) in de huidige maand worden uitbetaald.
•	Administratieve Rapportages:
o	De admin kan per werknemer een overzicht zien van:
	Gewerkte uren
	Overuren
	Thuiswerkbonussen
	Salaris en contractgegevens
•	CSV-Export:
o	Er moet een exportfunctie zijn waarmee de admin een CSV-bestand kan downloaden met de volgende gegevens per werknemer:
	Naam
	E-mailadres
	Datum van registratie
	Starttijd en eindtijd
	Aantal gewerkte uren
	Aantal overuren
	Salaris 
2.5 Instelbare Parameters en Configuratie
•	Instelbare Werkuren:
o	Mogelijkheid voor de admin om per werknemer het verwachte aantal werkuren per 4-weken periode in te stellen.
•	Overurentarief:
o	Voor iedere werknemer kan het tarief voor overuren worden vastgesteld (bijv. 10 euro per overuur).
•	Flexibele Periode-Indeling:
o	Het systeem moet automatisch de 4-weken periode berekenen op basis van de eerste werkdag van de werknemer.
________________________________________
3. Niet-Functionele Eisen
3.1 Gebruiksvriendelijkheid
•	Intuïtieve en overzichtelijke gebruikersinterface.
•	Responsive design zodat het systeem op zowel desktop als mobiele apparaten functioneel is (optioneel).
3.2 Veiligheid
•	Beveiligde login en opslag van gebruikersgegevens.
•	Toegangscontrole zodat werknemers en admin alleen toegang hebben tot hun eigen (of toegestane) data.
3.3 Performance
•	Snel en efficiënt verwerken van gebruikersinvoer en berekeningen.
•	Adequate schaalbaarheid zodat het systeem bij groei van het aantal gebruikers niet in prestaties achteruitgaat.
3.4 Onderhoudbaarheid en Uitbreidbaarheid
•	Modulariteit in de code-architectuur zodat toekomstige wijzigingen en uitbreidingen eenvoudig kunnen worden doorgevoerd.
________________________________________
4. Systeemarchitectuur en Technische Specificaties
•	Technologieën:
o	Webapplicatie (mogelijk op basis van moderne frameworks).
o	Beveiligde API’s voor communicatie tussen de front-end en de back-end.
•	Dataopslag:
o	Relationale database voor het opslaan van gebruikersgegevens, urenregistraties en rapportagegegevens.
________________________________________
5. Acceptatiecriteria en Testscenario’s
•	Gebruikersbeheer:
o	Werknemers kunnen zonder problemen inloggen en hun profiel aanpassen.
o	Admin kan gebruikers aanmaken, bewerken en verwijderen.
•	Urenregistratie:
o	Registratie van uren met starttijd, eindtijd, categorie en beschrijving werkt foutloos.
o	Het systeem berekent automatisch de gewerkte uren, overuren en thuiswerkbonussen.
•	Rapportage en Export:
o	De rapportages tonen correcte gegevens per maand, inclusief overuren uit voorgaande maand.
o	De CSV-export bevat alle vereiste gegevens en is leesbaar in standaard spreadsheet-software.
•	Flexibele Periode-Indeling:
o	Bij een afwijkende startdag wordt de 4-weken periode correct berekend en worden overuren nauwkeurig geregistreerd.
________________________________________
6. Conclusie
Dit eisenformulier beschrijft de basisfunctionaliteiten en randvoorwaarden voor het urenregistratiesysteem voor Hyred. Het systeem moet zowel voor de werknemers als de admin een duidelijk overzicht bieden van de geregistreerde uren, de berekende overuren en de toegekende thuiswerkbonussen. Daarnaast moet de admin volledige controle hebben over gebruikersgegevens en de mogelijkheid hebben om uitgebreide rapportages te genereren en te exporteren.

Top, ik heb het volgende er van gemaakt:
Beleidsaanbevelingen
Om de motivatie en mogelijkheden van bewoners in de wijk Liendert verder te onderzoeken en gerichte beleidsmaatregelen te formuleren, zijn hieronder drie kernadviezen uitgewerkt. Deze punten richten zich op het bereiken van moeilijk benaderbare groepen, kennisvergaring en sociale netwerken. Dit zijn de drie punten waar naar aanleiding van dit onderzoek de meeste winst op te pakken is, in het kader van de energietransitie.



Bereiken van Moeilijk Benaderbare Groepen
Uit het onderzoek blijkt dat specifieke groepen in Liendert minder goed worden bereikt, zoals bewoners met lage inkomens, taalbarrières of een gebrek aan urgentie. Dit vormt een belemmering voor inclusieve beleidsmaatregelen. Een aanvullend onderzoek moet zich richten op de behoeften en belemmeringen van deze groepen.

Vergroten van Kennis en Bewustwording
Een groot deel van de bewoners blijkt zich bewust te zijn van klimaatverandering en energiebesparing, maar specifieke kennis over concrete maatregelen en beschikbare middelen is beperkt. Een onderzoek kan zich richten op het identificeren van de belangrijkste kennistekorten en belemmeringen voor energiebesparend gedrag.

Stimuleren van Sociale Netwerken
Sociale netwerken spelen een cruciale rol in de verspreiding van kennis en motivatie voor energiebesparing. Bewoners geven aan veel te leren van familie en vrienden, maar niet iedereen heeft toegang tot deze netwerken. Onderzoek kan zich richten op de dynamiek van sociale interacties en hoe deze benut kunnen worden om duurzame gedragsveranderingen te stimuleren.

Zou je dit nog iets verder kunnen uitleggen per stukje, en schrijf het als een universiteit student sociologie (hoef je niet te vermelden, meer voor het inleven en woordgebruik) doe dit in het nederlands graag

- Een review sectie met reviews van eerdere klanten
- Call to action, iets van: Waar wacht je nog op?! 
- Footer

name: Timer and Stopwatch Web Apps
examples: a single page webapp that lets the user set a simple timer. it should look modern, sleek and dark mode pallete. the timer should look like an actual timer watch highly detailed

A dark mode compativle stopwatch app, that records the time when the snapshot was made and the time since sttart.

Add some animations and effects.
A dark mode compativle stopwatch app, that records the time when the snapshot was made and the time since sttart. We want lots of animations and effects. It must be beautiful.

Multi-stopwatch application that allows me to create new stopwatches, start and pause them. Each stopwatch can have some name attached to it. There is a possibility to manual modification of each stopwatch state, so that for example I can create a new stopwatch and start it from 5 minutes instead of from 0. Most of the time I want to see a dashboard with clean and bold geometric design, prioritizing readability - including readability from far away, when the app is displayed on large screen.
I don't want to have separate button or input for modification. When I click on the time it should pause and enter "editable" state. After the modification it should return to the previous state (if it was running, it should start running again). Also, when I add new stopwatch it should start immediately. Additionally, I don't need the input form for creating new stopwatch visible all the time, I want to see only the "+" button and see the inputs after I click it.
When I click on of the stopwatches to edit it, I should see the time in exactly the same format as it's displayed when it's running. Ie. when the stopwatch says "1:02" and I click it, I should have an editable input that says "1:02". When I input "2:10" it should convert it to appropriate value and modify the state.
I prefer bold minimalistic design optimised for a large screen. There is no need for Reset button, Pause button could be represented with a simple icon, not with the word "Pause".
If I don't provide a stopwatch name, it shouldn't be possible to create it. In the footer I want to see a short one-liner joke referencing the features of the application. There should be 10 jokes that rotate each 10 seconds. In the header there should be no text, but I would like to see a simple SVG representation of a stopwatch.

* Appear randomly at the top of the screen with varying sizes 
* Fall under Earth's gravity (9.8 m/s²)

* Interact with other letters, ground, and screen boundaries 
* Have density properties similar to water 
* Dynamically adapt to screen size changes 
* Display on a dark background

 Create a realistic physics-based animation of falling letters that:

-Have a 1/4 chance of being red, blue, yellow, or white
-Fall under Earth's gravity (9.8 m/s²)

Additionally, when two differently colored letters collide:

-Rules: R + B → Y, Y + W → R, R + W → B, Y + B → R.
-Collision Phase: The younger letter changes to the color directed on these Rules, while the older letter is removed.
-If a letter collides with n-number of corresponding letters in quick succession that all follow the Rules, then the first pair to collide triggers a Collision Phase, and the following ones do not happen. Basically, three letters can’t become one. 
Simultaneous collisions should not occur.

name: React 3D and Animation Components
examples: Generate React components using Tailwind CSS to create a variety of engaging and unconventional loading spinners. These should move beyond simple rotating circles or dots and instead represent specific actions or scenarios. Focus on creative and visually interesting movement using transforms, transitions, and Tailwind's utility classes. The components should be functional and easy to integrate into a larger React project.

Generate React components using Tailwind CSS to create a variety of engaging and unconventional loading spinners. These should move beyond simple rotating circles or dots and instead represent specific actions or scenarios. Focus on creative and visually interesting movement using transforms, transitions, and Tailwind's utility classes. The components should be functional and easy to integrate into a larger React project.

Please provide at least four distinct spinner examples, each with a different theme. Include the full React component code (with comments explaining the logic) and suggestions for how to adjust the speed and color easily via props.

Here are the themes to inspire you:

The Drummer: A spinner that simulates a tiny drummer playing a kit. Think of using <div> elements or similar to represent drums and sticks. The animation should look like the sticks are hitting the drums. Consider using subtle shadows or color changes to enhance the depth of the animation. Make the drummer fun and somewhat quirky looking, perhaps with oversized limbs.

The Brick Layer: This spinner should simulate someone building a brick wall, one brick at a time. Use simple blocks to represent the bricks. Animate them sliding into place from the bottom or side with a short, satisfying delay between each brick being placed. Consider having each brick change color slightly as it's added to make it more dynamic. Focus on a sense of construction and progress.

The Gardener: Depict a small plant growing from the ground. Start with just a seed or small sprout and gradually have leaves and maybe even a flower grow upward. Make this spinner look playful and organic, focusing on smooth animation and flowing lines. Use color changes to enhance the sense of growth.

The Scribbler: Create a spinner where an imaginary pen is drawing a shape, perhaps a spiral or a simple geometric pattern. The animation should suggest the hand moving a pen across a canvas. Use a line or a series of dots that appear sequentially as if being drawn. Explore different styles of drawing, maybe a very fast scribbling one or a slow, measured drawing one.

Key aspects to include in each spinner component:

Clear, concise React code: Use functional components and follow best practices.

Tailwind CSS for styling: Utilize Tailwind's utility classes for a consistent and efficient styling approach.

Configurable props: Allow for easy customization of speed (animation duration) and color (primary color) using React props.

Descriptive comments: Explain how each spinner works, making it easy for others to understand and modify.

Responsive design: Ensure the spinners scale reasonably well across different viewport sizes. They should remain visually balanced.

Optimized animation: Aim for smooth, performant animations that don't cause stuttering or lag.

Accessibility considerations: Ensure that a loading message is present or at least alt text for screen readers. (even if hidden from view)

Bonus Challenge:

Try incorporating some subtle background elements or particles to further enhance the visuals without being overly distracting.

Explore the use of SVG for more complex shapes and animations, if applicable.

### Instructions for Creating a Customizable Spinner Wheel in React

#### Objective:
You will build a customizable spinner wheel where users can:
- Specify how many options are on the wheel.
- Set custom labels for each option.
- Customize the color of each section on the wheel.
- Spin the wheel and display the selected option.

---

### **1. Initialize the Project**
- Set up a React project using either Create React App or Vite.
- Install any necessary dependencies. You may use a CSS framework like TailwindCSS if preferred.
- Create the main component structure for your spinner wheel.

---

### **2. Define State Variables**
You will need several state variables to handle user input and interactions:
- **Number of options:** Track how many sections the wheel should have.
- **Labels:** Store the text for each section of the wheel.
- **Colors:** Allow customization of the colors for each section.
- **Spinning:** Track whether the wheel is spinning or not.
- **Selected Option:** Store the result after spinning.

---

### **3. Create an Input Form for Customization**
Develop a form to let users define the wheel’s settings:
- **Option Count Input:** Allow users to enter how many options they want (e.g., a text input or number input).
- **Labels Input:** Provide a dynamic interface where users can add/edit labels based on the number of options.
- **Color Picker:** Include a color picker or input field to allow users to select custom colors for each section.

---

### **4. Build the Wheel Layout**
- Use an SVG or Canvas element to render the wheel dynamically.
- Divide the wheel into equal sections based on the number of options.
- Apply the colors and labels to each section.
- Use math functions to calculate the angles for each segment (360° divided by the number of options).

---

### **5. Implement the Spin Logic**
- Implement a "Spin" button to start the animation.
- Use CSS keyframes or JavaScript animation (e.g., `requestAnimationFrame`) to rotate the wheel.
- Randomly determine where the wheel will stop and calculate the winning section.
- Use easing functions (optional) to make the spin feel smooth and realistic.

---

### **6. Display the Result**
- After the wheel stops spinning, highlight or display the selected option.
- You can also provide an alert or update a section on the page with the result.

---

### **7. Add Enhancements**
Consider adding additional features:
- **Animation Effects:** Add sound effects or visual flares when the wheel spins or stops.
- **Save/Load Presets:** Allow users to save and load custom wheel configurations.
- **Mobile Responsiveness:** Ensure the UI looks good on different screen sizes.

---

### **8. Test the Component**
- Test the wheel by entering various numbers of options, labels, and colors.
- Ensure that spinning works correctly with different configurations.
- Verify that the correct option is highlighted when the spin ends.

---

### **9. Final Touches**
- Clean up your code by removing unnecessary comments and optimizing performance.
- Add comments where necessary to explain complex logic (e.g., rotation calculations).
- Deploy the final project to a hosting platform like Vercel, Netlify, or GitHub Pages.

---

### **10. Submit**
- Submit your project by sharing a link to the deployed site and your code repository.
- Include documentation describing your implementation process, challenges faced, and any additional features you added.

---

### **Grading Criteria**
- **Functionality:** The wheel should allow full customization and spin properly.
- **Design:** The interface should be user-friendly and visually appealing.
- **Code Quality:** The code should be clean, organized, and well-documented.
- **Testing:** The wheel should handle edge cases (e.g., no labels or colors provided).

Follow these instructions carefully and be creative!

name: Glucose Logging UX Design
examples:
a streamlined UX design for quick glucose logging, optimized for speed and minimal interaction:

1. Home Screen (Floating Action Button)
Quick Add Button: Persistent circular FAB at bottom right

Recent Entries: 3 most recent combinations at top (e.g., "After Breakfast", "Fasting")

2. Data Entry Overlay (Appears on FAB Tap)
A. Glucose Input (Default Focus)

Large numeric display (3 digits)

Input options:

Numeric keypad (large buttons)

Swipe up/down on number to adjust

Recent values quick-select (3 vertical bubbles)

B. Smart Context Cards (Below Input)
Auto-suggestions based on time:

5-9 AM: [Fasting | Breakfast | Before]

11 AM-2 PM: [Before Lunch | After Lunch]

5-8 PM: [Before Dinner | After Dinner]

Tappable chips with full context (e.g., "After Dinner ➔")

C. Manual Selections (If Needed)

Reading Type

Horizontal picker: [Fasting][Before][After][Random]

Visual cues:

Icon + text

Active state highlight

Meal Selection

Icon buttons: 🥞 Breakfast | 🥗 Lunch | 🍝 Dinner

Auto-highlight based on time range

Tappable to change

D. DateTime

Smart default: "Now" (70% of cases)

Edit via:

"Now" button (resets to current time)

"Earlier" → compact scroll-wheel picker

3. Optimized Flow
Best Case (3 taps):

Tap FAB

Enter glucose (keypad)

Tap suggested context card

Auto-submit

Full Manual Entry (5 taps max):

Tap FAB

Enter glucose

Select reading type

Select meal

Tap Submit

4. Post-Submit
Auto-clear form (reset to current time)

Brief confirmation toast

Option: "Log Another" quick-reopen button

Key UX Features:
Time-Based Intelligence

Meal suggestions by time ranges

Reading type probabilities (AM → Fasting)

Gesture Controls

Swipe left/right to cycle between common combinations

Swipe down to dismiss

Visual Hierarchy

Bolder colors for frequent actions

Progressive disclosure of advanced options

Error Prevention

Range alerts for extreme values (e.g., <40 or >400 mg/dL)

Auto-format glucose entry

Create a glucose logging webpage with a mobile-first design, prioritizing minimal taps and typing. The interface should include:

1. A large, centered number pad input for glucose value entry, with a prominent "Save" button at the bottom.

2. A date field that defaults to the current date but allows editing via a calendar picker.

3. A "Reading Type" section with four large, touch-friendly buttons: Fasting, Random, Before, After.

4. A "Meal" section with three large buttons: Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner.

5. An optional insulin field with a smaller number pad input.

6. A clean, modern layout with ample padding, soft shadows, and a light background color for better readability.

7. Large, circular buttons for meal and reading type selection, with clear labels and contrasting colors.

8. A header with the current date and time, updated automatically.

9. A save button that provides haptic feedback and a visual confirmation when pressed.

10. A professional color scheme using blues and grays, with high contrast for buttons and inputs.

11. Responsive design that works well on both mobile and desktop screens, with a maximum width of 600px on larger screens.

12. Smooth animations for button presses and form validation errors.

create a user-friendly UX for collecting glucose-related information multiple times a day, we can follow these principles:

Minimize Taps and Typing:
Use input fields with smart defaults or auto-fill suggestions based on previous entries.
Implement voice input or scanning capabilities (e.g., scanning insulin pens or food labels) to reduce manual entry.
Utilize sliders or steppers for numeric inputs like glucose values.
Quick Access to Frequent Actions:
Provide a prominent "Add Entry" button or floating action button for easy access to logging data.
Implement shortcuts or gestures (e.g., swipe gestures) for frequently used actions like logging meals or insulin doses.
Smart Defaults and Context-Aware UI:
Automatically populate fields like date and time based on the device's clock.
Use the device's location or time of day to suggest default meal types (e.g., breakfast, lunch, dinner).
Intelligently pre-fill fields based on previous entries or user patterns (e.g., suggesting the last insulin dose or meal type).
Streamlined Workflows:
Group related fields together and present them in a logical order (e.g., glucose value, reading type, meal, insulin).
Use tabs, carousels, or swipe gestures to navigate between different sections or entry types.
Implement auto-advance or auto-focus to move the cursor to the next field after completing an entry.
Visual Cues and Feedback:
Use color coding or icons to differentiate between reading types (fasting, random, before/after meal).
Provide clear visual feedback when an entry is successfully logged or when there are errors or missing fields.
Implement reminders or notifications for logging entries at specific times or intervals.
Here's a potential UX flow for logging glucose-related information:

The app opens with a prominent "Add Entry" button or floating action button.
Tapping the "Add Entry" button opens a streamlined form with the following fields:
Glucose Value: A slider or stepper input with smart defaults based on previous entries.
Date: Automatically populated with the current date, but editable if needed.
Reading Type: A segmented control or dropdown with options like "Fasting," "Random," "Before Meal," and "After Meal."
Meal: A dropdown or carousel with options like "Breakfast," "Lunch," "Dinner," and "Snack." The options can be context-aware based on the time of day or previous entries.
Insulin: A section with fields for "Meal Time Insulin," "Basal Insulin," and "Correction Insulin." These fields can have auto-fill suggestions based on previous entries or insulin regimens.
As the user fills out the form, the app provides visual cues and feedback, such as color coding for different reading types or meal icons.
After completing the entry, the user can tap a "Save" or "Log" button, which provides confirmation feedback and clears the form for the next entry.

An app that that assists in configuring Tandem insulin pump ranges on a graph with import and visualisation of Nightscout API data.

Allow for selecting and creating different Pump Profiles. Each profile has a set of time segments (e.g. "12:00 AM", "6:00 AM", "8:00 AM", "5:00 PM"), each time segment has a Start Time (when the time segment starts in 12 hour time, in increments of 30 minutes), a Basal Rate (in units per hour, e.g. 0.725, allowing custom numbers up to three digits and increments of .05), a Correction Factor, (e.g. 1 u : 35 mg/dL, with only the right side of the ratio the carbs being configurable, increments of 1), a Carb Ratio (e.g. 1 u : 8 g, with only the grams on the right being customizable, increments of 1), and a Target BG (e.g. 110 mg/DL, increments of 5 from 80 to 150). Time segments can be created or removed. They are automatically arranged from earliest to latest.

With time ranges configured, it should also display a graph showing the various configured time segment metrics (with correction factor most visible). It should allow uploading an image onto the graph that can be resized and moved and cropped on the graph to overlay a screenshot from one's Dexcom graph onto the pump time range graph.

Make it mobile-friendly, with a modern, iOS Swift-like appearance and a dark and blue layout. Allow importing from the Nightscout API with a Nightscout instance URL and token to add average blood sugar at specific times in the day across selectable time period to the graph to overlay over the pump time segments. Nightscout token is inputtable into the Nightscout url with ?token=TOKEN

## NIghtscout API info
Nightscout API

The Nightscout API enables direct access to your DData without the need for direct Mongo access. You can find CGM data in /api/v1/entries, Care Portal Treatments in /api/v1/treatments, and Treatment Profiles in /api/v1/profile. The server status and settings are available from /api/v1/status.json.

By default the /entries and /treatments APIs limit results to the the most recent 10 values from the last 2 days. You can get many more results, by using the count, date, dateString, and created_at parameters, depending on the type of data you’re looking for.
Example Queries

(replace http://localhost:1337 with your base url, YOUR-SITE)

    100’s: http://localhost:1337/api/v1/entries.json?find[sgv]=100
    Count of 100’s in a month: http://localhost:1337/api/v1/count/entries/where?find[dateString][$gte]=2016-09&find[dateString][$lte]=2016-10&find[sgv]=100
    BGs between 2 days: http://localhost:1337/api/v1/entries/sgv.json?find[dateString][$gte]=2015-08-28&find[dateString][$lte]=2015-08-30
    Juice Box corrections in a year: http://localhost:1337/api/v1/treatments.json?count=1000&find[carbs]=15&find[eventType]=Carb+Correction&find[created_at][$gte]=2015
    Boluses over 2U: http://localhost:1337/api/v1/treatments.json?find[insulin][$gte]=2 Allow quickly creating and editing new segments by clicking and moving points on the graph to configure start times. Fix the graph image overlay upload to upload a screenshot of the CGM data graph. Clean up the UI.

These are the non-negotiable features for daily use:

Quick-Logging Actions (1-Tap or Gesture-Based)

Glucose Entry: Allow manual input (with pre-set units: mg/dL or mmol/L) via:

A large numeric keypad.

Voice input (e.g., "Glucose 120").

Insulin Logging:

Type (bolus, correction, basal).

Units (with smart defaults based on user history).

Quick buttons for common doses (e.g., 2U, 4U).

Meal Logging:

Simple photo upload (optional) + carb estimate (auto-suggestions based on past meals).

Quick tags (e.g., "Breakfast," "Snack," "High-Carb").

Medication Tracking:

Pre-set medication list (user-defined).

One-tap logging (e.g., "Metformin: Taken").

Unified Timeline View

A clean, chronological feed showing glucose readings, insulin doses, meals, and meds.

Color-coded entries (e.g., red for high glucose, blue for insulin).

Tap to edit/delete entries (no hidden menus).

Smart Defaults & Shortcuts

Frequent Actions: Let users pin their most-used features (e.g., "Log Glucose" on home screen).

Time-Based Suggestions: Auto-prompt logging after meals or at typical testing times.

Bolus Calculator: Optional but helpful (hidden behind a "Need help?" button to avoid clutter).

Minimalist Dashboard

At-a-Glance Stats: Today’s average glucose, total insulin, carbs.

Trend Arrows: Simple icons (↑, ↓, →) for glucose trends.

Weekly/Monthly Charts: Basic line graphs (tap to expand).

UX Principles to Reduce Clutter
Progressive Disclosure

Hide advanced settings (e.g., carb ratio adjustments) under "Advanced" toggles.

Example: A basic insulin log asks only for units and type; carb ratios or correction factors are optional.

Zero-Typing Workflows

Use swipe gestures (e.g., swipe left to log glucose, right for insulin).

Pre-fill time/date with "Just Now" as the default (edit if needed).

Contextual Help

Add a small "?" icon next to complex terms (e.g., "correction bolus") that explains them in plain language.

Declutter the Home Screen

Only show the 4 core actions: Log Glucose, Log Insulin, Log Meal, Log Meds.

Hide trends/reports in a separate tab (e.g., "Insights").

Here's a UX design that aims to minimize taps, typing, and provide quick access to frequent actions for logging glucose readings multiple times a day:

1. Home Screen:
   - Display a prominent "Log Reading" button at the center of the screen.
   - Show a summary of the user's recent glucose readings and trends.

2. Log Reading Screen:
   - Glucose Value Input:
     - Provide a numeric keypad for entering the glucose value.
     - Use a large font size for easy readability.
     - Set the cursor focus on the input field by default.
   - Date and Time:
     - Auto-populate the current date and time.
     - Allow the user to adjust the date and time if needed by tapping on the field.
   - Reading Type:
     - Display buttons for common reading types: Fasting, Random, Before Meal, After Meal.
     - Highlight the most likely reading type based on the time of day and the user's past logging patterns.
     - Allow the user to customize and reorder the reading type buttons in the app settings.
   - Meal Selection (if applicable):
     - If the user selects "Before Meal" or "After Meal," display buttons for common meals: Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner.
     - Highlight the most likely meal based on the time of day and the user's past logging patterns.
   - Quick Log:
     - Provide a "Quick Log" button that logs the reading with the auto-populated and highlighted values.
     - Place the "Quick Log" button prominently at the bottom of the screen for easy access.
   - Manual Adjustment:
     - Allow the user to manually adjust the values if needed before logging.
     - Provide a "Log" button next to the "Quick Log" button for manual submission.

3. Confirmation Screen:
   - Display a confirmation message after the reading is logged successfully.
   - Provide options to "Add Note" or "View Summary" from the confirmation screen.
   - Include a "Log Another Reading" button to quickly log another entry.

4. Summary Screen:
   - Display a summary of the user's glucose readings for the day, week, or month.
   - Use visual charts and graphs to showcase trends and patterns.
   - Allow the user to tap on a specific reading to view or edit its details.

5. Settings Screen:
   - Provide options to customize the app's behavior and preferences.
   - Allow the user to set reminders for logging readings at specific times.
   - Enable the user to customize the reading types and meals displayed on the Log Reading screen.

6. Accessibility:
   - Ensure that the app is accessible to users with visual impairments.
   - Provide large, high-contrast text and buttons.
   - Support screen reader functionality for navigation and data input.

By following this UX design, users can quickly log their glucose readings with minimal taps and typing. The auto-populated values, quick log option, and customizable preferences aim to make the logging process as convenient and efficient as possible. The summary screen provides insights into the user's glucose trends, while the settings allow for personalization to suit individual needs.

name: Web Application Development for Business Management
examples:
Develop a visually stunning, interactive, and responsive web application with smooth transitions and 3D elements for a bottle manufacturing company, featuring: secure employee login (name, optional ID) and admin accounts; reactive clock in/out with timestamping; piece-by-piece production tracking for "Joint" and "Oil" bottles (admin can add types/sizes); insightful reporting on hours, production, productivity, and inventory; future phase with machine learning-driven production prediction; all while replacing a legacy paper-based system and designed for 5-10 users with minimal growth.

Phase 1: Time and Production Tracking (Current Focus)

Core Functionality:

User Authentication:
Implement a basic login system for employees using their name and an optional ID.
Include administrator accounts with the ability to manage employee data and system settings.
Clock In/Out System:
Provide clear "Clock In" and "Clock Out" buttons.
Accurately record timestamps for each shift.
Piece-by-Piece Production Tracking:
Develop an interface for employees to log the number of bottles produced during their shift.
Allow employees to specify the bottle type ("Joint" or "Oil").
Include a system for administrators to add new bottle types and sizes in the future.
Data Storage:
Store all time and production data in a database. Choose a suitable and reliable database system for a web application.
Reporting:
Generate reports showing individual employee hours worked and bottles produced per shift or per day, broken down by bottle type.
Include reports that provide insights into employee productivity and inventory levels (specific metrics to be determined).
Allow administrators to view and export data for all employees. Data export format is not critical at this time.
Responsive Design:
Ensure the web app is accessible and functional on various devices (desktops, tablets, smartphones).
UI/UX Considerations:

Intuitive Interface: The app should be easy to use, even for employees who may not be tech-savvy.
Clean Design: Avoid clutter; focus on essential elements.
Clear Visual Feedback: Provide clear visual cues when actions are performed (e.g., button clicks, data submission).
Phase 2: Production Prediction (Future Development)

Core Functionality:

Data Analysis:
Utilize machine learning algorithms to analyze historical time and production data.
Identify patterns and trends in production rates.
Predictive Modeling:
Develop a model that can predict future bottle production based on factors like employee, time of day, day of the week, historical production rates, and bottle type.
Prediction Visualization:
Display production predictions in a clear and understandable format (e.g., graphs, charts).
